results.title: VFX in Peter Rabbit
results.credit_line:
PR1: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™, the Movie ©2018 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
PR2: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™ 2:The Runaway, the Movie ©2021 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
results.brief_description: A look at how acclaimed VFX studio Animal Logic bought Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit to life.

constellations_primary.name: VFX to fantasy and freedom
constellations_primary.description: Founded in Sydney, and now with offices worldwide, Animal Logic are an Academy Award-winning VFX and animation studio whose job is to bring the impossible to life. And they're in good company with these other artists and filmmakers.

results.description: First springing from the mind of Beatrix Potter, Peter Rabbit is a creature that has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the beloved character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live action and animation for Peter Rabbit (2018), they used prop rabbits during the shoot so cast members had a tangible property to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
description_for_label: Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live-action and animation for Peter Rabbit, they used prop rabbits during the shoot for cast members to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
results.credit_line_for_label:
PETER RABBIT™ & © FW&Co. PETER RABBIT™ Movie © 2021 CPII All Rights Reserved

Special thanks to Columbia Pictures

results.title: The Pitch
results.brief_description: Films aren’t always plotted from start to finish. In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding.

constellations_primary.name: The Pitch
constellations_primary.description: Explore fantastical worlds and underwater seascapes.

results.description:
Films aren’t always plotted from start to finish. In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding. Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers, storytellers and visual artists.

Conrad Vernon was a storyboard artist on Shrek (2001) and co-director on Shrek 2 (2004), as well as the voice of the Gingerbread Man in the series. In this scene from Shrek, Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man to find the whereabouts of Duloc’s exiled fairytale creatures.

Tom McGrath was a storyboard artist, writer and co-director on the Madagascar trilogy, as well the voice of Skipper in the series. In this scene from Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa (2008), the zoo animals take off in a rickety plane with high hopes of it returning them safely to New York City.

results.title: Shrek storyboard pitch
results.brief_description: Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.
results.description:
Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.

Animated films aren’t always scripted from start to finish, so teams of artists collaborate on developing scenes and stories they then perform to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film.

Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers and storytellers as well as visual artists. Vernon was definitely a triple threat, and his performance as Gingy in the pitch was so impressive that he voiced the fan-favourite character in the movie.
description_for_label:
Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.

Animated films aren’t always scripted from start to finish, so teams of artists collaborate on developing scenes and stories they then perform to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film.

Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers and storytellers as well as visual artists. Vernon was definitely a triple threat, and his performance as Gingy in the pitch was so impressive that he voiced the fan-favourite character in the movie.

results.title: Mad Max V8 Interceptor replica
results.material_description:
fibreglass, steel, aluminium, plastic, glass, epoxy resin, automotive paint,
vinyl, leather, nylon carpet
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.
results.description:
George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979–85) cemented its place in pop culture. Thirty years later it roared back onto screens with a ‘reimagining’ featuring instantly classic new characters like Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron) and the War Boys.

Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

results.title: Tina Turner in Coober Pedy
results.brief_description: “I love listening to music while I’m working, and the music gives me ideas for the pictures. I might be listening to Tina Turner and that reminds me of when Tina was in the movie Mad Max 3 in the sparkly silver dress. Mad Max is filmed in the Outback and looks just like Indulkana, so I start thinking about what it might be like if Tina came to my community.” -Kaylene Whiskey
results.description: “I love listening to music while I’m working, and the music gives me ideas for the pictures. results.title: Mad Max: Fury Road
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979-85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.

constellations_other.name: Outlaws and the end
constellations_other.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

constellations_other.name: Storyboards to Academy Awards
constellations_other.description: Storyboards allow filmmakers, showrunners and game designers to visualise and communicate how their stories will look on-screen.

results.description:
Tom Hardy takes the Mad Max baton in this gloriously insane action film that explodes new life into the series and redefines the action genre. Along for the ride is Charlize Theron, who proves her action credentials and whose character, the fierce Imperator Furiosa, has branded herself into popular psyche and culture alike.

After years in the making George Miller set a bomb under contemporary actions films, abandoning overused CGI for insane practical effects and stunts that thrilled audiences worldwide. Essentially one long furious chase, Fury Road still manages to pack an emotional and visceral wallop and is a surprising feminist parable to boot. Miller essentially handed budding filmmakers a masterclass on action cinema with this one of a kind experience.
description_for_label:
Tom Hardy takes the Mad Max baton in this gloriously insane action film that explodes new life into the series and redefines the action genre. Along for the ride is Charlize Theron, who proves her action credentials and whose character, the fierce Imperator Furiosa, has branded herself into popular psyche and culture alike.

After years in the making George Miller set a bomb under contemporary actions films, abandoning overused CGI for insane practical effects and stunts that thrilled audiences worldwide. Essentially one long furious chase, Fury Road still manages to pack an emotional and visceral wallop and is a surprising feminist parable to boot. Miller essentially handed budding filmmakers a masterclass on action cinema with this one of a kind experience.

results.title: Mad Max
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979-85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

results.description:
Starring the then little known Mel Gibson, this low-budget box-office smash also launched the career of director George Miller and would be followed up by three more sequels. Set in a post-apocalyptic lawless world, Mad Max can be credited for inventing a genre and opening up the global market for Australian films.

The seeds were planted for Miller’s thrilling post-apocalyptic Oscar winning opus, Mad Max Fury Road with his debut film which set the bar for breathtaking car stunts and brutal violence. Using to great effect iconic Melbourne locations such as the Melbourne University car park and Victoria’s expansive country roads, it’s a wonder that this now classic and highly influential film didn’t spearhead an Australian film industry made up of post-apocalyptic road movies.

“Stunts themselves would be nothing without a filmmaker behind the camera and George Miller, a doctor and film buff making his first feature, shows he knows what cinema is all about” - Variety
description_for_label:

Using to great effect iconic Melbourne locations such as the Melbourne University car park and Victoria’s expansive country roads, it’s a wonder that this now classic and highly influential film didn’t spearhead an Australian film industry made up of post-apocalyptic road movies.

results.title: Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome
results.credit_line: Courtesy Kennedy Miller Mitchell Films Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979-85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.
results.description:
Taking an unexpected direction from the genre Miller established with his highly influential previous films, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome finds our reluctant hero coming face-to-face with the feudal Aunty Entity (Tina Turner), who lords over Bartertown and the deadly battle arena, Thunderdome.

Less emphasis on car chases and more on the brutal tribal world Aunty Entity and her minions reign over, the film sees Max leading a band of feral orphans to freedom. Never fear though, Beyond Thunderdome still bristles with mind-boggling retro-fitted cars, hair-raising stunt work, bizarre costumes and intricate world building to make this third entry into the series as white-knuckled as its predecessors.
description_for_label:
Taking an unexpected direction from the genre Miller established with his highly influential previous films, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome finds our reluctant hero coming face-to-face with the feudal Aunty Entity (Tina Turner), who lords over Bartertown and the deadly battle arena, Thunderdome.
